open_prs.title: Add build on each commit to main
Use flashbots-toolchain action to download reth
open_prs.body: This PR uses the `flashbots-toolchain` action to download `op-reth` for the integration tests.

open_prs.title: Add support for multiple builder and block selection

open_issues.title: Rollup Boost Status Page
open_issues.body:
Similar to how MEV-boost relays offer a [status page](https://boost-relay.flashbots.net/) which shows their registered validators, most recently received payloads, and more, we should have something like this on rollup boost which the sequencer can run which shows how many block builders are delivering payloads, as well as latencies, and eventually likely some other relevant features around flashblocks. Details about the block builder and TEE attestations also may be servable over this component but likely not done inside of the rollup boost logic.

The implementation of this is likely that rollup boost stores the data in-memory for the sequencer window and offers it to another service that indexes the data to make it available to a webpage that end users can go to.

open_issues.title: Circuit Breaker
open_issues.body: Similar to the idea of a circuit breaker for mev-boost on L1, rollup boost should auto shut off a block builder if multiple invalid payloads come from that block builder. TBD what turning the builder back on looks like. https://hackmd.io/@ralexstokes/BJn9N6Thc

open_issues.title: Document How Rollup Boost Handles Reorgs
open_issues.body: Title is self-explanatory, some caveats here are that we should frame things in terms of OP stack terms like sequencing window size, drift, etc etc. https://specs.optimism.io/glossary.html#sequencing-window

open_issues.title: Document Invalid or Bad Payload Response from Block Builder
open_issues.body:
There are two scenarios:
- What happens if the block builder gives an invalid block to rollup boost and the seqeuencer
- What happens if the block builder responds with a status 200 message such as "syncing"

open_issues.title: Document Rollup Boost Release Testing Process
open_issues.body: Document our process for being confident each rollup boost release does not contain any bugs, issues, memory leaks, etc. The goal should not be to develop and design an impenetrable line of defense, but to take the immediately high value efforts and document them.

open_issues.title: Block Builder Creator Log or Metric
open_issues.body: Rollup Boost should log or provide a metric for who built a block that it received. Discretion is available to the developer for whether this is a log or a metric.

open_issues.title: Document how debug API + dry run mode work
open_issues.body: Dry run builder mode and debug RPC were introduced in https://github.com/flashbots/rollup-boost/commit/22b0846866a5b5758b86c95f9da58f74e6cfe082 and we need documentation for how to use this mode and API.

open_issues.title: Production Concerns Documentation
open_issues.body: This is a tracking issue for a variety of questions that have come up from Uniswap and World team's when taking rollup boost to production.

open_issues.title: Add an integration test to validate that the builder cannot send bad blocks
open_issues.body: Add an integration test to check that the builder cannot send wrong blocks (i.e. wrong hash) to Rollup-boost since it checks first with the EL node. An idea could be to implement a proxy in between Rollup-boost and the builder to inject wrong data.

open_issues.title: Remove PayloadID field in FCU request if not doing block building
open_issues.body:
Whenever Rollup-boost receives a FCU update without payload attributes it logs this message when it calls the builder
```
2025-02-09T10:16:04.643822Z  INFO rollup_boost::server: called fork_choice_updated_v3 to builder with payload attributes url=http://localhost:8553/ payload_status=VALID payload_id=""
```
It is confusing to have `payload_id=""` since this call does not generate a payload id. We should print a different log in that case.

open_issues.title: Flashblocks Rollup Boost Design Doc
open_issues.body:
Add internal design document to docs repo in this repo. (design document has been internal solely because we're iterating and didn't want to confuse)

Will be nice to give system-level view (op-node, op-geth, batcher, RPC provider) and which parties need to run forked software

open_issues.title: More metrics
open_issues.body:
Having latency metrics for:
- rpc calls to local execution node (with rpc method as attribute) in proxy.rs
- engine api metrics
     - separate them to builder vs local call
     - in particular forkchoiceupdatedv3 by whether it has_attribute, and no_tx_pool is set
- multiplexed rpc metrics, separated by local vs builder call

open_issues.title: Possible Service Routing Issues on Kubernetes
open_issues.body: Hi there. We've noticed some odd behavior running Rollup-Boost on Kubernetes. Initial configuration: - Rollup-Boost in a Deployment running behind a Service. - Sequencer in an isolated StatefulSet running behind a Service. - AWS EKS 1.30 - Flashbots' Rollup-Boost pre-built container from Dockerhub, version [0.3rc4](https://hub.docker.com/layers/flashbots/rollup-boost/0.3rc4/images/sha256-475553fe8e290b61964a5172eec8b020fa1d086d50e039d27c56972a95a15242) - Network topography is pretty simple: One VPC, three AZs, one private/public subnet per AZ, Kube worker nodes deployed to the private subnets, LBs deployed to the public subnets. Security Groups on the cluster workers prevent communication from the outside world unless it ingresses through a load balancer. Nodes egress through NAT Gateways on the private subnets. Routing tables are barebones, no NACLs. When pointing Rollup-Boost at the Sequencer's Service ports using Kubernetes local DNS endpoints (`*.svc.cluster.local`), we would see timeouts: We were able to use Foundry's `cast` tool to connect to locally port-forwarded connections to the Pods and get the chain ID for both the builder and L2 back-end targets. We were also able to connect to any of the Pods in question (except Rollup-Boost as it doesn't look like it ships with an interactive TTY) and use `telnet` or `curl` to confirm connectivity to the back-end targets via the Service ports. When we redeployed the Rollup-Boost container directly into the Sequencer Pod and used `localhost` to refer to the back-end targets, everything worked fine out of the box. Just wanted to see if there have been any other reports or experiences you may have on running in this configuration? Thanks for any insights!

open_issues.title: Trait for block selection rule
open_issues.body: Rule for block selection from the builder e.g. max profit, more bridge txs etc

open_issues.title: Read inputs from config file (and updates at runtime)
open_issues.body: Rollup-boost could read the inputs from a config file. Then, we could use this config file to do updates at runtime.

open_issues.title: Use multiple builders
open_issues.body:
`Rollup-boost` could take as an input an array of builders, multiplex FCUs to all of them and decide during GetPayload step which builder returns the block with the highest value.

I think we should consider as well whether this should be built-in behaviour or something we can add behind a trait and have different flavours of rollup-boost.

open_issues.title: Reuse same JWT token from op-node for proposer op-geth
open_issues.body:
I think it makes sense that if `rollup-boost` is a middleware sidecar for proposer op-node/op-geth we can reuse the same JWT token we receive from proposer op-node to send the requests to proposer op-geth.

Then, the `jwt-token` flag would represent the jwt token between `rollup-boost` and builder `op-geth`.

closed_prs_last_week.title: Cleanup Integration + builder down integration test
closed_prs_last_week.body:
This PR does several things:
- It cleans up a little bit of the integration framework (introduces functions to start/stop/restart the services).
- It connects through P2P the EL and Builder instances of the integration test harness.
- It introduces a new test that checks that the builder can be stopped, rollup-boost does not fail and once the builder gets restarted the system goes back to normal.

closed_prs_last_week.title: Add debug api + dry-run builder mode
closed_prs_last_week.body:
This PR introduces a new debug API and dry-run mode functionality for the rollup-boost builder. The debug API allows runtime control over builder behavior.

Key Changes

- Implements a new debug API server running on port 5555 (configurable)
- Adds dry-run mode functionality that can be toggled at runtime
- In dry-run mode, builder get_payload calls are skipped, allowing for testing without blocking on the builder to return the block.
- Introduces new CLI commands for controlling debug features
- Adds integration tests for dry-run functionality

Closes #82 #8

closed_prs_last_week.title: Do not query builder if it is not building the block
closed_prs_last_week.body: With this PR we do not query get_payload from block builder if we know that it is not building the block during no_tx_pool request calls. Before, this showed as errors in the logs as the builder did not have any reference to the payload.

The PR changes the flag `--boost-sync` that enabled boost sync with a new flag `--no-boost-sync` which disables it if not required.

closed_prs_last_week.title: fix: Fix RPC module initialization
feat(da-throttling): Forward DA throttling and other `miner_` requests to the builder
closed_prs_last_week.body:
ref #48 

This PR introduces logic to support DA throttling by forwarding `miner_ ` requests to the builder. 

For `miner_setMaxDALimit`, [the  MinerApiExtServer from op-alloy-rpc-jsonrpsee](https://docs.rs/op-alloy-rpc-jsonrpsee/0.9.6/op_alloy_rpc_jsonrpsee/traits/trait.MinerApiExtServer.html) was implemented. Since the [MinerApi
from Reth is synchronous](https://github.com/paradigmxyz/reth/blob/e2c45f2b1fd5a0c50f2440175a61e23410ca06ee/crates/rpc/rpc/src/miner.rs#L14-L24) and the `rollup-boost` implementation has async calls, I recreated the trait within `rollup-boost` to be async. We can open an issue on Reth and use the trait from `reth-rpc-api` once this is upstreamed.


Feel free to let me know any feedback on the approach and if you have a preference on how to extend or amend the current test harness to best test this feature.

closed_prs_last_week.title: feat(da-throttling): Forward `miner_` requests to the builder
closed_prs_last_week.body:
This PR introduces logic to support DA throttling in the builder by forwarding `miner_` requests to the builder, following the same convention in the `EthApiServer` implementation. 

Feel free to let me know any feedback on the approach and if you have a preference on how to extend or amend the current test harness to best test this feature.

closed_prs_last_week.title: chore: local -> external builder mapping
closed_prs_last_week.body:
# Overview
This PR adds payload ID mapping functionality to track and map between local and external payload IDs when interacting with the builder node. This ensures proper correlation between payloads across different nodes.

Key changes:
- Added `local_to_external_payload_ids` cache to `PayloadTraceContext` to store mappings
- Added methods to store and retrieve payload ID mappings
- Updated `get_payload_v3` to use external payload ID when requesting from builder
- Added payload ID mapping in `fork_choice_updated_v3` response handling
- Added logging improvements to track both local and external payload IDs

The changes help maintain proper tracing and correlation between local execution engine payloads and external builder payloads, improving debuggability and reliability of the system.


fixes #46

closed_issues_last_week.title: Dry Run Mode
closed_issues_last_week.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

Currently, Rollup Boost lacks a way to test interactions with external block builders in a production environment without jeopardizing the OP stack liveness. This makes network upgrades an all-or-nothing scenario, which introduces risk.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

Introduce a `--dry-run` flag to Rollup Boost that allows operators to:

- Propagate block requests to external builders without delivering them to the OP stack sequencer.

- Log interactions and outcomes for analysis.

- Expose metrics to verify the dry run mode's functionality.

**Implementation Details:**

- **Dry Run Flag:** Add a command-line option `--dry-run` that, when enabled, processes block requests from external builders but prevents their delivery to the OP stack sequencer.

- **Logging:** logging to indicate when Rollup Boost is operating in dry run mode, detailing interactions with external builders and any deviations from expected behavior.

**Exposed Metrics:**

To ensure confidence in the dry run mode's functionality, the following metrics should be exposed:

1. **Total Block Requests Sent:** The cumulative number of block requests initiated to external builders during the dry run.

2. **Successful Block Responses:** The count of valid block responses received from external builders.

3. **Failed Block Responses:** The number of block responses that failed validation or were otherwise deemed invalid.

4. **Average Response Time:** The mean time taken to receive responses from external builders after initiating a request.

5. **Skipped Block Deliveries:** The count of blocks that were processed but intentionally not delivered to the OP stack sequencer due to dry run mode.

6. **Error Logs:** Detailed logs of any errors encountered during interactions with external builders in dry run mode.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**

Currently, the only alternative is to test interactions in a separate staging environment, which may not fully replicate production conditions.

closed_issues_last_week.title: rollup-boost: Infinite engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV2 loop when proxying op-node to L2
closed_issues_last_week.body:
## Description
When using rollup-boost as a proxy between op-node and the L2 node, I notice repeated engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV2 requests that eventually cause an error on op-node. Specifically, the error is that it “cannot send engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV2,” and logs indicate that rollup-boost is stuck in a loop sending the same request.

The problematic call appears to be in [proxy.rs at line 145](https://github.com/flashbots/rollup-boost/blob/main/src/proxy.rs#L145):
```
// Original code that leads to infinite loop and error:
inner.call(req).await.map_err(|e| e.into())

// Changed to (fixes the loop and error):
forward_request(client, req, &method, l2_uri, l2_secret).await
```

it resolves the loop and allows op-node to function properly. I’m unsure why this particular modification fixes the issue or whether the root cause lies in the Docker networking setup. I was expecting tower to preserve all headers and successfully proxy request.

## Steps to Reproduce
1.     Clone the repository (main branch).
2.     Configure rollup-boost to proxy requests between op-node and your L2 node (possibly using Docker).
3.     Observe the infinite engine_forkchoiceUpdatedV2 requests and resulting error messages from op-node.
